docs.lead_paragraph: Evolution has not always come up with things people consider wonderful. Note mosquitoes, sickle cell anemia and the killer instinct. But according to evolutionary theory, there is a reason for everything that has evolved. However obnoxious it may seem, somehow it enhances survival. And so it seems that survival is the likely reason for morning sickness, survival not just of the unborn child but also of the pregnant woman who must bear the burden of its prenatal development. That is the conclusion of two Cornell University evolutionary biologists after examining the results of nearly 80,000 successful and unsuccessful pregnancies, correlating their findings with the incidence of morning sickness and the development during early pregnancy of food aversions and cravings.

headline.main: What Could Be Good About Morning Sickness? Plenty

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health article on research suggesting that morning sickness so common in early pregnancy is actually body's way of keeping women away from potentially contamined foods at time when fetus is especially vulnerable; Samuel M Flaxman and Dr Paul W Sherman of Cornell report that nausea and vomiting helps protect both mother and fetus from toxins that can lurk in in meat, fish, poultry and eggs, which are also foods to which pregnant women develop most aversions; women who suffer from morning sickness also have fewer miscarriages; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: And Baby Makes Good Copy While many women may have a hard time seeing pregnancy as a chance to take hold of new fashion opportunities, the British model Stella Tennant felt no such limitations. Ms. Tennant, a granddaughter of the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, has modeled for Burberry, the unstoppably trendy label of her homeland, since 1997. That she was five months pregnant at the time of the Burberry Fall 2000 show in London last February did not deter her from modeling an evening gown. And that she was seven months pregnant when it came time to shoot next fall's advertising campaign did not frighten her employers either.
docs.abstract: Front Row column on British model Stella Tennant modeling fashions for pregnant women for Burberry's; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Let me clarify Cardinal Roger Mahony's ''clarity'' on the right to choose (letter, June 2). This right is not just the right to have an abortion; it's the right to choose whether or not to have an abortion. A pregnant woman who chooses to have a child is exercising the same right as one who chooses to terminate her pregnancy; it's a ''seamless cloth,'' a single right protected by Roe v. Wade. If it's a woman's choice to make, then the government can't force her in either direction, no matter who she is.
docs.abstract: Theodore Jay Miller reply to Cardinal Roger Mahony's June 2 letter holds right to choose means right to choose whether or not to have abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: SAY what you will about the shake-up in New York's Senate race -- and there is so much to say that we'll be reading about it in the history books -- Rudolph W. Giuliani's withdrawal has given the public a choice. We had one before, but on personality much more than on substance, because Hillary Rodham Clinton and the mayor agreed on most major issues. Not so Mrs. Clinton and Rick A. Lazio, Mr. Giuliani's successor as the Republican candidate. The first lady and the congressman from Long Island do share some of the same positions and give themselves similar labels: he calls himself ''mainstream'' and she calls herself a ''centrist.'' But you get the impression that these two candidates would often vote differently in the Senate.

headline.main: Metro Matters; Candidates Who Agree To Disagree

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick Metro Matters column discusses how Hillary Rodham Clinton and Repr Rick A Lazio, opponents for US Senate from New York, differ on most issues (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Fuzzy Abortion Debate'' (editorial, May 27): You use the expression ''a woman's right to choose,'' but for some unknown reason, you fail to finish the thought. You say pro-life forces ''are now finding it more productive to chip away at a woman's right to choose.'' And you refer to candidates ''who promise to support a woman's right to choose.'' Choose what?

headline.main: In Abortion Debate, Clarity Should Rule

docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the stock characters in 20th-century English literature, few have survived in the public's imagination with greater tenacity than the inebriated Irishman, and the Irish Arts Center is offering a model of the stereotype with a revival of J. P. Donleavy's stage version of ''The Ginger Man'' by the Dublin Theater Company. Unfortunately, the specimen we encounter in the play, especially in the current production, emerges more as a garden-variety drunk than the boozy charmer Mr. Donleavy created first in a novel. Mr. Donleavy's enchantment with Ireland began after World War II. The American son of well-to-do Irish immigrants, he attended Trinity College, Dublin, on the G.I. Bill.

headline.main: Carousing Around Dublin in the Company of a Stereotype

docs.abstract: Wilborn Hampton reviews J P Donleavy's The Ginger Man as presented by Dublin Theater Co under direction of Ronan Wilmot at Irish Arts Center (M)
